text: Hello everyone.
Welcome to this session.
This is officially a discussion session rather than purely a music session.
The topic of this session is war, exile, separation, and musical resilience.
So music's in there, but it's about the role of music
as a source of strength, of spiritual strength, of inner strength for people who are going through

really terrible situations of exile, of having to leave their own lands and countries, resettlement, separation from families in some cases, and how music has helped them to revitalize themselves in new conditions.
So we will play some music.
You'll hear some music.
And I think we're going to have some improvised Japanese-Afghan fusion music.
Yes?
We're going to try.
We're going to try.
My name is Ted Levin, and I'm the presenter for this session.
Let me introduce the participants.
On my left, George Abe.
Next to George is Humayun Sahi.
And next to Humayun is Salar Nader.
Humayun and Salar are ethnically Afghan.
Their ancestry is in Afghanistan, but they live in California.
We're in the Sounds of California stage.
So everyone here, except me, I live in Vermont,
But the others all are from California.
George was born in California.
But in fact, he's the only one of the three who was actually born in California.
Humayun was born in Afghanistan and Kabul.
Yes, in Kabul you were born.
And Salah was born in Germany.
His family had already left Afghanistan by the time he was born.
But when I say that George was born in California, he was born in a very specific place and circumstance in California that makes him relatively unique.
George, tell us about where you were born.
I was born in Manzanar, California, about seven miles outside of Long Pine near Bishop.
And that's where I was born, during World War II.
My mother moved from San Pedro to the camp.
My father was in Los Angeles when he was relocated.
They married in camp, and I was born in camp.
5,000, 6,000 kids were born in those camps.
Love goes on, you know?
So, George, for people who don't know, could you just say what was the purpose of these camps?
Ostensibly, our protection.
One of the reasons was the Japanese were going to be hung and burned out.
That was one of the reasons.
And actually, too, the whole West Coast was filled with anti-Orientalism.

The Hearst newspapers, I mean, you know, the Grange, the Daughters of the American Revolution, they were really anti-immigrant, yeah, anti-immigrant, which is really scary, the whole thing going on today.
It's a, yeah, so that was the atmosphere, and Japanese were, you know,
Partly, I mean, the story is national security.
Again, the Japanese were living as fishermen in the port cities of San Pedro and up along Monterey.
And the Western Defense Command said, hey, they're a threat.
They're going to join hands with the Japanese army when the Japanese army lands.
Never happened.
And there was never any sabotage.
It's one of those lie kind of things that there was never evidence of sabotage, but it was going to happen.
You know, as a reason for Japanese being put in camps, yes.
So everyone in the Manzanar camp was Japanese?
Japanese, American citizens, and aliens.
So they were Japanese-American who had become American citizens.
Born here.
Born here, nonetheless, in the camps.
Yeah.
So there was a, I mean, we got reparations.
It was a big battle, but we did get some reparations.
And it was a long battle, but yeah, we fought for that.
It was wrong.
It was wrong.
Constitutionally wrong to put American citizens into camps.
Let's talk about music.
How did you come to be a musician and what inspired you?
My father played an instrument called a biwa.
A biwa?
Yeah, a lute-like instrument.
Actually, it's related to sitars.
It's called a
It's called a pipa in China.
And when it got to Japan, it became a biwa.
My mother was a poet.
She wrote in tanka, or Japanese poetry.
And I grew up in that milieu of artists and poets and musicians.
And so I was inspired to play.
I studied clarinet and saxophone in grammar school and high school.
And then about the time I went to college, I started really getting into bamboo.
Bamboo is just really important to Asian culture.
And this is, for example, this is a flute that I made from California bamboo, grown in my friend's backyard.
And like me, it's different from Japanese bamboo.
Japanese bamboo is hard and grows slow.
So that's a shakuhachi, yes?
This is a bamboo flute that was used by Buddhist priests as a form of meditation.
I have a friend who plays shakuhachi, and he has a little kind of schtick that he does at concerts.
He'll say, I'll give $50 to anyone from the audience who can come up and make a sound on this instrument.
And to this day, he's never lost $50.
It's very, very hard to play this instrument, even to make a sound on it.
George, show us what a shakuhachi sounds like.
Don't stop.
So you told me that your teacher was also in Manzanar.
Yeah.
My father and my teacher, they were both in the mountain police.
Really, more like keystone cops, mounted police advancement.
And my teacher, Bido Wakita, taught in Los Angeles before the war, 1940s, before 1940s, back in, I think, from the 20s and 30s.
He taught in camp, too.
Some people,
I had some music that was handwritten, copied from the teachers, because they didn't have a copy machine.
So handwritten Japanese music, copied from the teachers.
So this is a really interesting topic.
You're living in a camp, really under very debased conditions, and yet there's this urge to play music.
Where does that come from?
Well, I think for one thing, people were bored.
Nothing to do.
I mean, you're not working anymore.
I think some people were getting like $17, $18, $19 a day, doctors.
I meant like a day, a month, to be a doctor, you know, or to be a teacher.
But you're bored and you don't have things to do.
So there were teachers in camp of various cultures, flower arrangement, tea ceremony, and musical instruments.
There was a revival of interest, actually, in Japanese music and culture because of the camps.
And after the camps, those teachers thrived.
Because at the time that people were put into camps, for example, in central California, people were really spread out.
They didn't have much contact, maybe once a year during festivals.
But they didn't have much contact with being teenagers.
It was a great time for teenagers.
Yeah.
They met.
They fell in love.
There's all kinds of stories about that.
But for adults, it was terrible.
You lost your business.
You lost your house.
You lost.
You saw Farewell to Mansonite, the movie.
The woman trashes her beautiful dishes because she doesn't want to do them.
So in this respect, you share something with Humayun Sahi, who also spent a significant amount of time living in a refugee camp, in his case, in Peshawar, Pakistan, yes?
Tell us, Humayun, about that.
How did you end up leaving Kabul and coming to Peshawar?
Actually, I was in Kabul in 1992, but that time was war, and in the war I think music was not, you know.
They don't like music.
And that's why it also was war.
And I said, OK, I'm going to my father.
And everyone, they said, like, you have to move from here.
And we are going to Peshawar.
And I was in what we call Camp Nasserbakh.
We went there.
It was a refugee camp.
Refugee camp.
Yeah.
So you were there with your family?
Yeah, I was with my family.
Yeah.
And you had with you your rubab.
You brought a rubab.
Of course.
Without rubab, I'm... And so did you play music in the camp?
Actually, no.
It was the first time.
They said, like, there's no music.
Don't play.
Because the Mujahideen were running the camp.
Actually, yeah, because there was like... And they didn't approve of it.
And at the time also, the time was not good for music.
They said like... Also my father and my mother, she said like, don't play because you never know like... And I was so like, you know, without music I can't live.
But you ended up in teaching, yes?
You started a school in the camp?
Actually, yeah.
After, I think, one year and I opened a school for people and they came and I was teaching.
So did they also have rabobs, or you were teaching singing?
What did they do, the children?
Actually, rabob.
They also had rabobs in the camp.
And what do you think was the impact of this school in the camp?
Did it help raise people's spirits?
Did it create a sense of cultural identity?
Actually, the school, that was not in the camp.
That was, we called Takal, Takal Apoyin.
I was there.
That was not in the camp.
I see.
And then you ended up, how many years were you living in Pakistan before you came to Fremont?
I think from 92 to 2001.
Nine years.
Yeah, nine years.
And then you came to Fremont.
And what happened with your music when you came to Fremont?
Actually, I came here because there's a lot of opportunity and also a lot of Afghans.
I teach and also people love my music.
Humayun's being very modest, but he's in fact a major star in Fremont, California, where there's a very large Afghan population, 40,000 or so.
Afghans living in and around Fremont, which is near San Francisco.
So out of a total population of 220,000 in Fremont, about one in five people is of Afghan heritage or origin.
So there's a huge community.
And Humayun, it's safe to say, is the main or one of the main musicians who is performing in weddings.
Where do you perform in Fremont?
Everywhere.
Weddings, parties, concerts.
It's like the famous story about one of the famous German conductors.
He gets into a taxi and the driver says, where should I take you?
And he says, it doesn't matter.
They want me everywhere.
Exactly.
So you're playing in weddings.
Not a lot.
Yeah, some weddings.
Show us something on the Rabab.
What does this instrument sound like?
Play something for us.
Like some classic?
Afghan folk song, whatever you want.
OK.
I want to play just a little bit, some Pashto and from
Jalalabad and some from Mazar-e-Sharif, northern Afghanistan, some from Erad, some from Kabul.
First I am playing the Pashto a little bit.
Ž Ž Ž
Ž Ž Ž
Thank you.
And now I'm going to play a bit from Mazar-e-Sharif, Qataghan.
So this is from the north of Afghanistan.
North of Afghanistan, yes.
Mazar-e-Sharif.
Mazar-e-Sharif, yes.
And this style is called Qataghan, Qataghani.
Yeah, Qataghani, Qataghanzamin, we call, yeah.
It's a folk instrumental style.
If you want to dance, you're welcome to dance.
You'll feel the rhythm.
Anyone who's moved to dance, please.
Actually, usually people, they are, you know, in this piece, they are clapping.
Beautiful.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Humayun, you told me once that in those years in the camp in Peshawar, because you couldn't play music loudly because of the mujahideen, you practiced silently.
Is that right?
Just... Exactly, yeah.
But you're practicing like... Kind of a mute?
Yeah.
It's not giving you that feeling, you know?
And I'm practicing, I have to play harder.
You know, with this kind of technique, you can see how precisely he plays.
You know, you have to do that every day.
You have to practice to keep that power of technique.
So really, it's incredible that during those nine years, you were able to preserve your technique and come out of it.
Thank you.
Salar, you had a different kind of experience, yeah?
Hello, everybody.
I'm Salar Nader.
I'm kind of like the hybrid Afghan-American here via Germany.
How old were you when you came to the United States?
Ich was ein Jahre alt.
Ein Jahre alt, ja.
I was a year old, so I don't remember Germany.
And it was West Germany at the time.
But you grew up starting from age seven, yes, taking tabla lessons from the great master Zakir Hussain.
So kind of going back tracking to Hamburg, my family maintained, actually every Afghan family had either a set of tabla or a rubab.
or a harmonium, which is a kind of pumped organ instrument.
And that's what people would sing songs to remind them of Afghanistan, the homeland, and their experiences and memories that all they had to hang on to.
So in Germany, I was kind of like this confused baby pitter pattering on the drum, not knowing that in seven years I was going to meet my guru in Berkeley, California.
So I land in California, first day for tabla class.
And Ustad Zakir Hussain is teaching in a classroom about this size.
There's about 40 to 50 students who are ranging from the youngest student, maybe 35, up to about 80.
And in comes this seven-year-old following his dad.
My dad would carry my tablas for me.
And Zakir Hussain kind of looked at me and said, you can play tabla?
And I was so confident.
I was like, yeah, I'm going to belt out some Afghan rhythms.
So I kind of like, and that's all I was playing at the time was folk Afghan rhythm that could go along with any Afghan folk songs and material.
So you've spent years developing your technique, practicing six, eight hours a day.
Every day, six to eight hours a day.
And now you're teaching, yeah?
And I've been teaching.
Tell us about how you teach.
It's so interesting.
In our era of globalization, of diaspora communities, with all the war that's torn Afghanistan apart for really the last 25 years.
40 years.
Well, 40 years.
I was in Afghanistan in 1974.
And that might have been the last time that it was calm.
And I just turned 35 last week.
So we're going to add three, four years.
But in this era where you have Afghans living literally all over the world, how do you work with your students?
So thank you to, here's my endorsement deal, Skype.
I meet students online.
So I met three students yesterday morning from Germany, Singapore, India, Kabul.
As long as you got a decent Wi-Fi connection, you can meet these students.
And so I'll meet, you know, there's actually hundreds of them online and also in person.
It's great because all these students come from different backgrounds and different styles of music.
So you have some students who want to learn pure classical traditional tabla solo because that's what I've been taught is how to be a soloist when you learn tabla.
And then you kind of have to learn the rules of the ring.
When you meet someone like Umayoun Sahi, OK, so this is how you accompany Rabab.
All of Afghanistan's provinces and regions have a musical style of its own.
So you're using social media as a... For teaching.
For teaching.
And you have students in Afghanistan itself?
Oh, yeah.
I teach at the Afghan, the Aga Khan Institute for Music in Kabul.
I've taught there.
And also through students who come through from the Afghan National Institute of Music.
And then now, you know, it's like these kids,
All they hope for is some way, some form of enjoyment, some light in their life.
So music and arts is the one untainted, uncorrupted way of being able to express yourself and find some enjoyment in the everyday happenings in Afghanistan.
So we land and it's like, oh yes, the classroom's packed.
These kids have an outlet finally.
That's fantastic.
So here's an interesting example of a diaspora community that's really providing the musical nourishment for the source place.
It's our duty.
We have to go back.
And it's just no matter what happens there or here, we have to spread the love.
And that's one thing.

We I said this yesterday we're trying to shine our light as bright as we can and just sing through our instruments and bring The peace and love which we really need at a time like this You spoke about learning to play tabla solo show us a little bit of what a tabla solo sounds okay, okay
Well, Tabla is an oral language, so... National Folk Festival, Sounds of California.
I'll do these on the tabla.
Bravo.
Thank you.
George, back to you.
What's the instrument in front of you?
So George, what is this instrument?
It's a drum used in Buddhist temples.
It's kind of a signaling device to begin chanting or to begin meditation.
And it takes you into a quiet state, right?
Actually, if you're up here, you can put your ear on it.
It's still weak.
It's still weak.
But it's interesting to me.
I heard you're really into Silkroad.
But Silkroad would basically trade, as we looked at it.
But metallurgy.
So Buddhism came to Japan and you're a practitioner, yes?
And music is a part of your practice?
Yes, it is.
For example, I played a flute in an orchestra called Karakun.
Karakun is a form of music that goes back to the Tang Dynasty, China.
It no longer exists in China, but it's part of the imperial household music department in Japan.
We were lucky at UCLA to study under Professor Suemo Utogi, who was of the family,
But families were given responsibility for instruments of the Kayaku group.
And he is, he turns back to 780.
So he took on a group, and the Kayaku orchestra is incredible.
It's a whole different feeling.

So these instruments, the Japanese instruments, obviously they're quite different from the Afghan instruments in terms of the scales, the tuning, the sensibility, but can we see what happens if we try to put them together?
Improvisation, it's the spice of life.
Welcome to a live experiment.
Ž Ž Ž
Bravo.
So how did they do, do you think?
That was a new piece.
I wanted to close my eyes and just meditate and listen to both of you just go for a while.
So it was really a massage to my ears.
You have to record some beats.
Well, I think this offers a nice metaphor for the possibilities of harmony.
Harmony, of course, it's at the center of music, but also we understand harmony in a broader sense, a social sense, metaphorical sense.
So this is maybe a good thing to try to do in life as well as in music.
harmonizes.
We're just about out of time.
Yeah, we have two or three minutes.
Just let me, I'd like to thank the sponsors, and then maybe we'll go out with some music.

The sponsors of this Sounds of California stage and of this event include the Alliance for California Traditional Arts, Radio Bilingue, the American Folklife Center at the Library of Congress, and the Aga Khan Music Initiative, which is part of the Aga Khan Development Network.
It's a large international development network

that's working in Afghanistan, among other places, and support schools, music schools in Afghanistan where both Salar and Humayun have been teaching to try to revitalize those traditions and pass them along.
So thank you to all the sponsors.
Let me also mention that tonight at 630 on the Ralph Rindler stage just here Humayun and Salar will be performing a full concert an hour and a half of Afghan music.
So if you'd like to hear more of this music in its more traditional form, please come out free concert at 630.
Why don't we end with some sounds?
A couple of minutes.
You choose.
So,
Seriously.
Oh yeah
Thank you very much, Salar Nader, Humar Ansaki, George Aden.
Thank you, Professor Ted Levin.
It's such an honor to be here with all of you.
Thank you.
Sixth Thursday, Rensselaer stage.
Bring your dancing shoes and your sunblock.
Stay put.
In about five minutes, we'll have sounds of California, Chicano, Son Jarocho, and Japanese-American festival music, Fandango Bon.
Stay put.
Jim, is the program 90 minutes?
th th
Yes, actually,
Yeah, I wanted to just move it away from the outside just so we can keep an eye on it.
